title: The marketing genius of Lil Nas X
desc: This is the story of how Lil Nas X went from college dropout sleeping on his sister’s couch to breaking Mariah Carey’s record for the most consecutive weeks at No. 1 — in just seven months.

title: The best word of mouth strategies in the world
desc: Less than 1/1000 businesses have a proper word of mouth strategy. Yet they pull in customers just as reliably as paid ads for a fraction of the cost.

title: How to write a landing page title
desc: Most things in marketing are unimportant. And we stress about them. Landing page headlines are important. And we don't stress about them. I've spent the past fortnight reading 500 landing page titles and talking to copywriting experts. This is what I've learnt:

title: Turning a restaurant robbery into a viral ad
desc: On the 16th December 2015 Frijoles & Frescas Tacos gets robbed. The next day, store owner, Greg Carlson, releases the security footage. Except he's added captions which turn the burglary into a story about how all the thieves wanted was their delicious tacos.

title: Refactoring UI: A lesson in high prices
desc: How Adam Wathan and Steve Schoger escaped the dogma of e-book pricing and made $1.35M selling Refactoring UI, their design book.

title: How I got 2,000 new subscribers from Product Hunt
desc: Last Wednesday I launched Marketing Examples to Product Hunt. It received more than 1,500 upvotes, was voted Product of the Week, and my email list zoomed from 1,300 to 3,300 in the space of 72 hours. This is the step by step account of how I did it.

title: How Nomad List dominates longer tail keywords
desc: A detailed case study explaining how Nomad List autogenerates several thousand indexed pages which hoover up organic traffic from long tail keyword phrases.

title: The Indie Hackers newsletters
desc: Indie Hackers is an online community of independent entrepreneurs, with a pretty sizeable email list. Throughout 2019 they’ve moved away from one generic email digest and started offering users the option of up to eight tailored newsletters

title: The genius of Tesla's marketing strategy
desc: Tesla have zero advertising budget. The focus is on turning customers into fans. The result is quite an extraordinary marketing strategy which I've broken down:

title: Let your customers write your copy for you
desc: Copywriting doesn't require the “perfect line” or a “flash of inspiration”. Just talk to your customers, listen to what they're saying, and let them do the work for you. This article explains how Design Academy does just that

title: Using GIPHY for free brand awareness
desc: All you need is a Giphy brand channel. Then any GIF you upload is publically available on Giphy's search engine. And there's nothing stopping you slipping in your logo, product, or even URL.

title: How Rev. Chris grew 100k Instagram followers
desc: For two and and a half years Rev. Chris Lee's Instagram account grew steadily. He posted mostly pictures of himself, his family, and the church. In July 2019 things changed. Chris started uploading “60 second sermons”.

title: 6 keys to sharing content on Twitter
desc: How you share is just as important as what you share. In one second someone subconsciously decides whether to engage with your content on Twitter or to scroll by. These tips are about optimising for that one second.

title: How Volvo won the Super Bowl (without running an ad)
desc: How Volvo's interception stole the show at the 2015 Super Bowl. Whenever you saw any other car commercial during the Super Bowl you could win a Volvo XC 60 for a loved one. All you had to do was was tweet why they deserved the car using the hashtag #VolvoContest during the commercial.

title: 7 practical ways to write copy that converts
desc: Conversion copywriting is an art. Here are 7 practical tips that you can implement today to make your landing page convert better.

title: SEO project marketing
desc: Make side projects. Host them on your own domain. Get them in front of the press. The idea is press exposure results in articles (and backlinks). And because the projects are hosted on your own domain any “link juice” flows to other pages on your website helping them rank better.

title: Podia's hub of competitor comparison pages
desc: How Podia built a hub of “[competitor] + alternative” pages pulling in 5,500 organic traffic each month

title: Basic SEO and Specsavers' FAQ page
desc: The most common SEO mistake is relying on a single page website. Every new page is a new opportunity to target and rank for a search term. So if you’re dumping all your content on one page you’re limiting the number of search terms you can rank well for.

title: CD Baby's confirmation email
desc: Back in 1998, when Derek Sivers first founded CD Baby, their order confirmation email was the regular: “Your order has shipped today. Please let us know if it doesn’t arrive. Thank you for your business.”

title: How to get Tom Hanks on your podcast
desc: This article explains how Chris Hardwick from the Nerdist podcast used a vintage 1934 Smith Corona typewriter to quite creatively bribe Tom Hanks onto the Nerdist podcast back in 2012.

title: How to build a website which converts email subscribers
desc: 12.9% of first time Marketing Examples users end up as a email subscribers. It's fair to say it's one of the best websites in the world at converting passers-by into email subscribers. This case study gives a step-by-step analysis.

title: What to do if Joe Rogan recommends your product?
desc: Iron Neck found themselves in the much sought after position of having Joe Rogan recommend their product. Well, they chopped up the footage into a video and ran ads targeting Joe's audience.

title: The 1903 Tour de France
desc: The 1903 Tour de France was set up as a “side project” which ended up changing the fortunes of its parent newspaper L'Auto

title: Marketing tools are damaging your SEO. And how to fix it.
desc: It's no secret that a site's “performance” is a ranking factor for search. But how does Google actually measure it? Well, open up Chrome DevTools, click the Audits tab, then Run Audits and you'll see that “Performance” is made up from 6 metrics

title: How to get 30,000 Hacker News visitors to your website
desc: How Adriaan van Rossum drove more than 30k visitors to his website from Hacker News

title: Why Notion's sign-up form converts so well
desc: In three years looking at landing pages, I’ve never come across a sign-up flow better at converting than Notions. Let’s get into it.

title: How Jason Cohen does direct sales
desc: How Jason Cohen got his first 30 users before even building his product.

title: How Jeff Johnson sold Nike's first shoes
desc: The story of how Phil Knight and Jeff Johnson drove to track meets all over the Pacific Northwest and sold more shoes than you can imagine out of the boots of their car.

title: How Fortnite changed the way video games were marketed
desc: How Fortnite flipped the growth funnel on its head and forever changed the way video games are marketed.

title: Reaching 3.7 million people posting canvases to YouTubers
desc: 140 Canvas printed bespoke canvas', posted them to the PO boxes of YouTubers around the world and ended up with their product getting seen by over 3.7 million people.

title: How step by step keyword research led to an SEO goldmine
desc: How keyword research led Thomas Cook to an SEO goldmine and which pulls in an additional 450,000 organic users per month ...

title: A much improved newsletter sign up flow
desc: Asking to be added to your recipients' address book results in much improved email open rates

title: Costly Signalling Theory
desc: An awareness of costly signalling theory is invaluable in understanding the psychology of marketing.

title: Becoming an antifragile brand. Ft. Lewis Capaldi & KFC
desc: What Lewis Capaldi and KFC can teach you about becoming an antifragile brand.

title: Growing 2.5 million subscribers piggybacking on viral trends
desc: How two 16 year old Canadian friends made several hundred thousand livestreaming the PewDiePie vs T-Series battle.

title: How Tweet Photo designed virality into its product
desc: How Tweet Photo grew from 0 to 1,700 users purely through organic referral.

title: The key to self promotion on Reddit
desc: Reddit is a bit of an untapped goldmine for marketers. The site is made up of thousands of niche communities (subreddits). This gives an opportunity to communicate directly with your audience.

title: 100 thank you cards. $5,200 extra revenue
desc: How Mailing Out 100 Thank You Cards Earned Skinny Wimp Moving an extra $5,200 / mo

title: Serve a niche market. Get more attention
desc: Why targeting a niche market was the key to the Yeezy Dating website going viral. A detailed analysis.

title: Try writing “advice emails” instead of sales emails
desc: Why asking your leads for advice converts far better than directly trying to sell to them.

title: How to write a funny cold email
desc: How Gusto uses thier cute company dog to get your attention when cold emailing. A detailed case study on how to cold email

title: Use Intercom to build customer goodwill
desc: How technology could be leveraged creatively to build even tighter bonds with customers. A case study on Baremetrics use of Intercom.

title: The “best sales email ever” from a personalised t-shirt company
desc: How Ramp T Shirts managed to personalise 50,000 messages and ended up with of the most successful cold email campaigns of all time. A case study.

title: How to build viral loops into your content marketing
desc: How to leverage the power of retweets to build viral loops into your content marketing campaign. A case study about how Javascript Grammar eBook was shared around all over twitter

title: Understanding the power of signalling
desc: Why extra effort and care in delivery of a message increases the perceived importance of that message

title: How 2 minutes of personalisation transforms your cold emails
desc: An example from Beamery showing just how easy it is to personalise your cold emails without sounding like a jerk.

title: How Amul marketed their butter cookies
desc: An example from Beamery showing just how easy it is to personalise your cold emails without sounding like a jerk.
